notes.title: Definition & Scope of IR (What examiners expect)
notes.content: Precisely define IR, distinguish it from International Politics and Foreign Policy, and outline scope: state and non-state actors, conflict & cooperation, international institutions, law, economics, and normative issues. Use this as a framing paragraph in any essay.
keyTakeaways: Start answers with a crisp definition + scope map.
Name the main actors (states, IGOs, NGOs, MNCs, epistemic communities).
Show evolution: from state-centric realism to pluralist and critical approaches.

resources.title: OUP — The Globalization of World Politics (book info)
resources.description: Overview of the text used worldwide in IR 101.

notes.title: National Power: Ingredients & Measurement
notes.content: Break power into tangible (population, economy, military, technology) and intangible (legitimacy, morale, leadership, diplomacy). Link to capability vs. influence debates and soft power. Use South Asia examples for application.
keyTakeaways: Power = capabilities + successful conversion to outcomes.
Cite both material and ideational components in essays.
Use SIPRI and World Bank figures for currency.

resources.title: SIPRI Yearbook 2024 — World Nuclear Forces (sample chapter)
resources.description: Current nuclear forces data for state power comparisons.

notes.title: Realism vs. Neorealism (Classical vs. Structural)
notes.content: Contrast classical Realism's focus on human nature and statecraft with Neorealism's systemic structure, anarchy, and distribution of capabilities. Add Waltz's levels of analysis and polarity debates; mention offensive vs defensive realism.
keyTakeaways: Classical: human nature, prudence (Morgenthau).
Neorealism: structure and relative gains (Waltz).
Use post–Cold War cases to show limits (institutions & norms matter).

resources.title: Harvard Kennedy School — Realism in IR (course page)

notes.title: Liberalism vs. Neoliberal Institutionalism
notes.content: Trace Liberal roots (commercial peace, democracy, law) to Neoliberalism's regimes & complex interdependence. Compare with Neorealism on absolute vs relative gains; use trade/IO examples.
keyTakeaways: Cooperation possible under anarchy via regimes and reciprocity.
Absolute gains logic underpins trade & institutions.
Interdependence changes costs of conflict.

resources.title: Keohane & Nye — Power and Interdependence (Ch.1–3 PDF)

notes.title: Constructivism vs. Realism (Ideas, Norms & Identity)
notes.content: Show how identities and norms shape interests and behavior. Contrast material power arguments with socially constructed meanings. Use examples like NATO's identity, R2P norms, and norm diffusion.
keyTakeaways: 'Anarchy is what states make of it' (Wendt).
Interests and identities are not fixed; they evolve via social interaction.
Use norm cascades and constitutive rules in answers.

resources.title: E-International Relations — Overview of Wendt's Constructivism
Wikipedia Overview (quick revision)
resources.description: High-level map of the approach (verify with scholarly sources).

notes.title: Changing Dimensions of Security (From State to Human Security)
notes.content: Contrast classical (state-centric, military) with widened security (economic, environmental, human security). Use post–Cold War and climate/conflict links.
keyTakeaways: Security has broadened (sectors) and deepened (referents).
Human Security reframes threats: poverty, health, climate.
Use UNDP framing and SIPRI human security chapter to update stats.

resources.title: SIPRI Yearbook 2024 portal
resources.description: Sample chapters on international stability & human security.

notes.title: Pre-emptive Self-Defence & Iraq 2003 (Law & Legitimacy)
notes.content: Anchor legal discussion in Article 51 and customary law (Caroline standard: necessity & proportionality). Evaluate US arguments on anticipatory self-defence and collective security vs. unilateral action.
keyTakeaways: Quote UN Charter Art. 51 and discuss 'armed attack' threshold.
Distinguish pre-emptive vs. preventive force.
Conclude with legitimacy vs. legality and UNSC role.

resources.title: Harvard PILAC — Catalogue of Article 51 Communications

notes.title: Responsibility to Protect (R2P): Norm Emergence
notes.content: Explain shift from non-intervention to responsibility-based sovereignty. Outline pillars and criteria for intervention; discuss mixed record in practice.
keyTakeaways: Sovereignty entails responsibilities to populations.
Three pillars: state duty, international assistance, timely and decisive response.
Contestation remains over authorization and selectivity.

resources.title: ICISS — The Responsibility to Protect (2001) PDF
Global Centre for R2P — ICISS report page

notes.title: International Political Economy: Liberalism, Dependency & Neo-imperialism
notes.content: Cover liberal trade gains vs. dependency/neo-imperial critiques. Use examples of conditionality, debt, and supply-chain asymmetries.
keyTakeaways: Absolute gains vs. dependency & structural power.
IMF/World Bank conditionalities as case material.
Tie back to national power & strategic culture.

notes.title: Non-Aligned Movement (History, Relevance, Current Positions)
notes.content: Define NAM's origins, Bandung & Belgrade, and role after Cold War. Use recent NAM communiqués to show contemporary stances.
keyTakeaways: NAM evolved from decolonization to broad Global South platform.
Still influential in UN diplomacy & norm signaling.
Use Kampala 2024 summit statements for current examples.

resources.title: AP News — NAM Kampala Summit coverage (2024)
resources.description: Recent NAM positions for contemporary references.

notes.title: Pakistan's Strategic Culture (Determinants & Evolution)
notes.content: Map traditional vs. non-traditional threat perceptions; civil-military dynamics; geography; identity; India factor; nuclear doctrine; shift toward complex security.
keyTakeaways: Historical legacies and regional rivalries shape doctrine.
Scholarly debate on moving beyond 'tunnel vision' to NTS.
Use recent Pakistani scholarship + external think-tank reports.

resources.title: Marines Corps Univ. — Foundations of Pakistan's Strategic Culture

Annals of Human & Social Sciences — Paradigm Shifts

notes.title: Deterrence & Nuclear Stability in South Asia
notes.content: Explain stability–instability paradox, escalation risks, and CBMs. Use Kargil–Balakot–crisis literature and current force estimates.
keyTakeaways: Offsetting capabilities deter major war but allow lower-level conflict.
Escalation control and communication channels are vital.
Use SIPRI numbers carefully with dates.

notes.title: US Indo-Pacific Strategy & Great-Power Competition
notes.content: Summarize the 2022 US Indo-Pacific Strategy pillars (free & open, connected, prosperous, secure, resilient). Link to China's rise and regional alignments.
keyTakeaways: Quote the official document for pillars and action plan.
Use for essays on containment/engagement and balancing.
Connect to Quad, ASEAN centrality debates.

notes.title: Diplomacy & Dispute Settlement (UN, ICJ, Bilateralism)
notes.content: Define diplomacy types (track 1/2/1.5), negotiation–mediation–arbitration, and link to Pakistan–India cases (Simla Agreement, Indus Waters as cooperative success).
keyTakeaways: In essays, structure by diplomatic instruments + case studies.
Explain when bilateralism vs. multilateralism is chosen.
Always add feasibility & limitations.

notes.title: Historical Conferences & Treaties (MCQ Revision Pack)
notes.content: Keep a ready MCQ sheet for Yalta, Versailles, Cuban Missile Crisis, Westphalia, NPT dates, NATO/SEATO/NAM formation years.
keyTakeaways: Memorize dates with one-line significance.
Tie facts to analytical essays when possible.
Use FPSC past papers to target repeats.

notes.title: Hybrid Warfare & Social Media (Information Operations)
notes.content: Define hybrid warfare and map information operations, cyber, economic coercion, and lawfare. Provide Pakistan-relevant examples and safeguards.
keyTakeaways: Hybrid blends kinetic and non-kinetic tools.
Social media manipulation is an IR & security issue.
Policy responses: literacy, regulation, resilience.

resources.title: SIPRI Yearbook 2024 — International stability & human security (sample)

notes.title: US–China: Thucydides Trap? Competing Interpretations
notes.content: Explain Allison's 'trap' thesis vs. critics; discuss balancing, economic interdependence, and issue-specific cooperation. Use Indo-Pacific strategy as a primary source.
keyTakeaways: Avoid deterministic claims; provide structural + domestic factors.
Combine power transition theory with interdependence.
Cite official strategies + academic critiques.

notes.title: Video Learning Playlists (Fast Revision & Concept Clarity)
notes.content: Use concise, structured playlists to revise theory, foreign policy, and levels of analysis. Pair with textbook chapters for depth.
keyTakeaways: Watch with a note-taking grid (theory | assumptions | policy implications).
Use for last-week revision + examples.
Supplement with OUP chapter MCQs.
